issue.title: [feature] support access token passed as header

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem ?

In Mastodon the access token can be passed in through the header `Sec-WebSocket-Protocol` since https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/10818. GTS should support this too, as some clients are now using this.

### Describe the solution you'd like.

Check the query param first and fallback to the header if the query param is empty.

### Describe alternatives you've considered.

None

### Additional context.

I can submit a PR for this if accepted.

issue.title: Styles and scripts not loading on Chrome browser in Android
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.13

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Linux

### Describe the Bug

For the website I'm developing, styles and scripts aren't loading on my android phone. It works on desktop. It works responsively (within the desktop).

**Edit**: the browser it's not working on is Google Chrome and device is moto g4. It's working on the Firefox browser.

Having inspected my android phone using chrome://inspect, I can see the style sheet and script seem to be loaded in fine, but the styles aren't applied and scripts aren't working.

I've made some attempt to reproduce the issue on the site.

An example is the home page: [here](https://joshua-gordon.netlify.app/).
I've made a simple page on: [here](https://joshua-gordon.netlify.app/test).

The git repository is at: [here](https://github.com/ruben00001/joshua-gordon-portfolio).


### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

None.

### Participation

- [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: Please provide a minimal reproduction.

issue.title: Is a directory (os error 21) - Internal Server Error
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

v.1.6.14

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

Deno

### What package manager are you using?

npm 8.19.2

### What operating system are you using?

Linux

### Describe the Bug

Please read [the issue on deno](https://github.com/denoland/deploy_feedback/issues/318).

tldr:

- `npm run dev` works perfectly,
- `npx astro build` has no problem,
- `npm run preview` shows an empty page
- when deploying to deno via [GH Actions](https://docs.astro.build/en/guides/deploy/deno/#github-actions-deployment), there's an `Internal Server Error`

Is Astro with GH Actions using this line?
```javascript
import { serve } from "https://deno.land/std@0.167.0/http/server.ts";
```

Is @astrojs/deno up to date or is it using this other line?
```javascript
import { serve } from "https://deno.land/std@0.132.0/http/server.ts";
```

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/abcd1234

### Participation

- [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

issue.title: Prefetch integration doesn't prepend the src path with the config.base

labels.name: p4-important
labels.description: Violate documented behavior or significantly improves performance (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.14  //  prefect is 0.1.1

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

Node

### What package manager are you using?

pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

linux

### Describe the Bug

When you add a base in the astro.config.mjs, it is not used by the prefetch integration in SSR mode.

Here is a discord support ticket with more details : [How can I prefix assets href in SSR ?](https://discord.com/channels/830184174198718474/1019713903481081876)

This is what I get with the base configured as 'dist/views' :
```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/dist/views/assets/404.07d04bcf.css" />
<script type="module" src="/page.5a6f3db5.js"></script>
```

And this is what I expect : 

```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/dist/views/assets/404.07d04bcf.css" />
<script type="module" src="/dist/views/page.5a6f3db5.js"></script>
```


### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://codesandbox.io/p/sandbox/frosty-glitter-we1x6f?file=%2Fastro.config.mjs&selection=%5B%7B%22endColumn%22%3A41%2C%22endLineNumber%22%3A11%2C%22startColumn%22%3A41%2C%22startLineNumber%22%3A11%7D%5D&workspace=%257B%2522activeFileId%2522%253A%2522cl8vqm78z0002lthi55o15wef%2522%252C%2522openFiles%2522%253A%255B%2522%252Fpackage.json%2522%252C%2522%252Fastro.config.mjs%2522%255D%252C%2522sidebarPanel%2522%253A%2522EXPLORER%2522%252C%2522gitSidebarPanel%2522%253A%2522COMMIT%2522%252C%2522spaces%2522%253A%257B%2522clbg8tv41000u3b6ggw4fddcz%2522%253A%257B%2522key%2522%253A%2522clbg8tv41000u3b6ggw4fddcz%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522Default%2522%252C%2522devtools%2522%253A%255B%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522UNASSIGNED_PORT%2522%252C%2522port%2522%253A3000%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522we1x6f-3000.preview.csb.app%2522%252C%2522key%2522%253A%2522clbg95eex029z3b6g8lfor6v7%2522%252C%2522isMinimized%2522%253Afalse%257D%252C%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522TERMINAL%2522%252C%2522shellId%2522%253A%2522clbg8zzwd00427qhifn67898s%2522%252C%2522key%2522%253A%2522clbg8zzrv00vo3b6gc9ffqhq0%2522%252C%2522isMinimized%2522%253Afalse%257D%255D%257D%257D%252C%2522currentSpace%2522%253A%2522clbg8tv41000u3b6ggw4fddcz%2522%252C%2522spacesOrder%2522%253A%255B%2522clbg8tv41000u3b6ggw4fddcz%2522%255D%257D

issue.title: an odd and unclear behaviour when using jsx-like syntax
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using? 1.6.12 ### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one? @astrojs/node@3.1.0 | Node.js version is 18.12.1 ### What package manager are you using? npm@9.1.3 ### What operating system are you using? Mac ### Describe the Bug When using the JSX-like syntax, the behaviour is a bit odd. Given this example, ```jsx --- const props = { class: "red" } ---

Should I be blue or red?

I'm neither blue or red.

I'm red.

``` The HTML output is, ```html

Should I be blue or red?

I'm neither blue or red.

I'm red.

``` The first `h1` is blue, so `props.class` is ignored. - This could benefit from a mention in docs, if it's intended The second `h1` is black, even though it receives the `red` class. - This seems like a bug The third `h1` is red. - This behaves as expected ### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-qkr4u8?file=src/pages/index.astro ### Participation - [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: I'm surprised that (2) does not receive the hash class name but (3) does. I would almost expect (3) not too, but then again I'm not super familiar with the hash assignment code. Maybe @natemoo-re has insight here.

+			return nil, gtserror.NewErrorInternalError(fmt.Errorf("error converting status to api: %s", err))

+

+			nextMaxIDValue = item.GetID()

+

+		}
+

+
+	return util.PackagePageableResponse(util.PageableResponseParams{
+		Items:            items,

issue.title: Redirect in imported pages throws an error
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.13

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

Node

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

When adding `Astro.redirect('/')` to a (imported) hidden page the application throws an error.
You can see the example in StackBlitz when navigating to `/en/search`

```
Returning a Response is only supported inside of page components. Consider refactoring this logic into something like a function that can be used in the page.
 error   {"size":0}
  File:
    /home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/file:/file:/home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/core/errors/utils.js:68:73
  Stacktrace:
Error: {"size":0}
    at Module.createSafeError (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/core/errors/utils.js:68:73)
    at onError (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/vite-plugin-astro-server/request.js:75:41)
    at Module.runWithErrorHandling (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/vite-plugin-astro-server/controller.js:86:19)
    at async Module.handleRequest (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/vite-plugin-astro-server/request.js:56:3)
```

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-kmhexi

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: You can only redirect from the top-level page. So in your case that would be in `src/pages/en/search.astro` or `src/pages/nl/zoeken.astro`. It's not a matter of where the component is located, if it's not used as a top-level page then it can't redirect (or return a response).

## Changes

While the `site` property in the Astro config can be accessed in the app via `Astro.site`, the `base` property is only accessible via `import.meta.env.BASE_URL`. It wasn't documented, so this PRs fixes this.

## Testing

No tests since it's just a docs change.

## Docs

This updates the types that are used to generate the reference pages (https://docs.astro.build/en/reference/).

issue.title: Add Astro.joinBase

labels.name: core
labels.description: PRs that modify the core `astro` package.

issue.body: Note that this PR is **just an experiment**. If it is successful then this might become an RFC. ## Motivation This PR is intended to aid when using `base` configuration in Astro. A common issue is that because Astro does not mutate your templates when you set things like `Contacts page ``` When using the base of `/docs/` that will produce `/docs/contacts`. ### join-base: directive However, since this is so commonly needed inside of the template this change also includes a directive `join-base:` which is used within your template to get the same effect, but without needing to create an expression and call the function. Here's the same example but used with the directive: ```astro Contacts page ``` ## Changes - Adds `Astro.joinBase` which can be used to join a URL to your configured `base`. `Astro.joinBase('/images/penguin.png')` becomes `/blog/images/penguin.png`. - Also updates the compiler which includes a `join-base:` directive to make it easier to use this feature within your template. ``` ``` ## Testing - None yet. Compiler has a test ## Docs - Docs added in Astro types - More needed, tbd

This PR was opened by the [Changesets release](https://github.com/changesets/action) GitHub action. If you're not ready to do a release yet, that's fine, whenever you add more changesets to main, this PR will be updated.


# Releases

### Minor Changes

-   [#5366](https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5366) [`081e0a9d2`](https://github.com/withastro/astro/commit/081e0a9d2070b23d596b687ad52ed3a68bc3ac24) Thanks [@smithbm2316](https://github.com/smithbm2316)! - Added the ability for users to include the full content of their posts/items in each RSS feed entry

^1.6.13

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

no

### What package manager are you using?

npm, pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

Windows, Linux

### Describe the Bug

I was trying to implement a Threlte component. It's a Svelte library for Three.js and it uses it's own pre-processor. (https://threlte.xyz/getting-started#installation)

I am getting this error:
``` error   Error while preprocessing C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/src/components/App.svelte - markup.update is not a function
  File:
    C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/src/components/App.svelte
  Stacktrace:
TypeError: Error while preprocessing C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/src/components/App.svelte - markup.update is not a function
    at Object.enter (file:///C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/node_modules/@threlte/preprocess/dist/index.js:121:32)
```

This is a repo to reproduce the error. Stackblitz example doesn't build either but I don't see full error message (could be just me not knowing where it outputs :P )
[https://github.com/jerzakm/astro-threlte-issue](https://github.com/jerzakm/astro-threlte-issue)

**Why it's broken**
It is happening because `magicstring.update` was released in 26.6 and astro uses `"magic-string": "^0.25.9"`
https://github.com/Rich-Harris/magic-string/commit/7b45b9bbb9890e78bb683edccc9a667ef159ddc0

**Quick fix**
Simply installing magic-string inside the project as dev dependency fixes the issue
`npm i -D magic-string`

**Permanent fix proposal**
Update astro's `magic-string`. I am not familiar with astro internals so I'm not sure if this would cause any major problems. I'm willing to make a PR with it.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-wmsgt4?file=src/pages/index.astro

### Participation

- [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: @jerzakm a PR would be very welcome here!

issue.title: Body tags are missing when conditionally rendering Astro components in HTML head
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.13

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

When conditionally rendering an Astro slot or component in the HTML `head`, the opening and closing `body` tags provided by the template are completely stripped from the document.

I'm using said condition to differentiate between a production or development build, and it appears to not make a difference whether the condition evaluates to true or false. Only commenting out the code does lead to the body tags being correctly rendered.

There is no difference in behaviour between a production build or running the development server.

It is hardly noticeable when using an empty body tag, because browsers seem to be fault-tolerant and implicitly insert one (as one can see in the dev console), but I am putting CSS class names on the body element which I need for styling. In this example I used an inline style so it's visible more easily.

Both slot content and Astro component, as well as the rest of the document seem to be rendered correctly.

I can kind of work around the issue by wrapping everything inside body in an extra div and apply my classes there, but this might not apply to everyone, so this is totally unexpected to me.

```astro
---
const isProd = process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production'
---
<html lang="en">
	<head>
		<meta charset="utf-8" />
		<title>Astro</title>
		{isProd && <slot name="test" />}
	</head>
	<body style="background-color: red;">
		<slot />
	</body>
</html>
```

A minimal reproducible example that is also rendering an Astro component is provided below.


### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-uwb7te?file=src/pages/index.astro

astro-rss: Generate feed with proper XML escaping (#5550)

* test(astro-rss): Compare XML using chai-xml

Signed-off-by: Anders Kaseorg <andersk@mit.edu>

pull_request.title: astro-rss: Generate feed with proper XML escaping
pull_request.body:
## Changes

Generating XML using string concatenation is dangerous and can lead to underescaping.

Just to preemptively dismiss some excuses for this unsafety 😛:

- _“But most of the content was surrounded with with `<![CDATA[…]]>`, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. The content might contain `]]>` itself and break out of the `<![CDATA[` early.
- _“But URLs don’t need to be escaped, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. `&` commonly appears in URLs and needs to be escaped for XML or HTML serialization.
- _“But we were validating the output XML, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. A bug that’s caught at generation time is still a bug; also, some cases of underescaping could lead to incorrect output that isn’t invalid.
- _“But there’s no user-generated content for an attacker to control, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. Underescaping is still a bug even when it’s not a security vulnerability.

So let’s take the `fast-xml-parser` library that we were using to validate our hand-rolled XML, and use it to properly generate XML instead.

## Testing

I updated the existing tests to compare the XML using `chai-xml`, so that the snapshotted XML strings didn’t need to change. This verifies that the new output is semantically equivalent.

## Docs

This doesn’t need any documentation changes. I even preserve support for the existing `customData` option by parsing and re-serializing the XML string.

pull_request.title: Fix Astro.params not having values when using base in SSR
pull_request.body:
## Changes

- Internal rendering expects `pathname` to be trimmed of the base because routing is not aware of base.
- Fix is to provide the pathname without base to rendering.
- `url.pathname` is still the real pathname. The other `pathname` is just used for internal route/param matching and not provided to the user.
- Fixes https://github.com/withastro/astro/issues/5537

## Testing

- New test case added

## Docs

N/A, bug fix

In Mastodon the access token can be passed in through the header `Sec-WebSocket-Protocol` since https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/10818. GTS should support this too, as some clients are now using this.

### Describe the solution you'd like.

Check the query param first and fallback to the header if the query param is empty.

### Describe alternatives you've considered.

None

### Additional context.

I can submit a PR for this if accepted.

labels.name: p4-important
labels.description: Violate documented behavior or significantly improves performance (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.14  //  prefect is 0.1.1

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

Node

### What package manager are you using?

pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

linux

### Describe the Bug

When you add a base in the astro.config.mjs, it is not used by the prefetch integration in SSR mode.

Here is a discord support ticket with more details : [How can I prefix assets href in SSR ?](https://discord.com/channels/830184174198718474/1019713903481081876)

This is what I get with the base configured as 'dist/views' :
```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/dist/views/assets/404.07d04bcf.css" />
<script type="module" src="/page.5a6f3db5.js"></script>
```

And this is what I expect : 

```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/dist/views/assets/404.07d04bcf.css" />
<script type="module" src="/dist/views/page.5a6f3db5.js"></script>
```

issue.title: an odd and unclear behaviour when using jsx-like syntax
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using? 1.6.12 ### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one? @astrojs/node@3.1.0 | Node.js version is 18.12.1 ### What package manager are you using? npm@9.1.3 ### What operating system are you using? Mac ### Describe the Bug When using the JSX-like syntax, the behaviour is a bit odd. Given this example, ```jsx --- const props = { class: "red" } ---

Should I be blue or red?

I'm neither blue or red.

I'm red.

``` The HTML output is, ```html

Should I be blue or red?

I'm neither blue or red.

I'm red.

``` The first `h1` is blue, so `props.class` is ignored. - This could benefit from a mention in docs, if it's intended The second `h1` is black, even though it receives the `red` class. - This seems like a bug The third `h1` is red. - This behaves as expected ### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-qkr4u8?file=src/pages/index.astro ### Participation - [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: I'm surprised that (2) does not receive the hash class name but (3) does. I would almost expect (3) not too, but then again I'm not super familiar with the hash assignment code. Maybe @natemoo-re has insight here.

+func (p *processor) BookmarksGet(ctx context.Context, requestingAccount *gtsmodel.Account, limit int, maxID string, minID string) (*apimodel.PageableResponse, gtserror.WithCode) {
+	if requestingAccount == nil {
+		return nil, gtserror.NewErrorForbidden(fmt.Errorf("cannot retrieve bookmarks without a requesting account"))
+	}
+
+	statuses, err := p.db.GetBookmarks(ctx, requestingAccount.ID, limit, maxID, minID)
+	if err != nil {
+		return nil, gtserror.NewErrorInternalError(err)
+	}
+
+	filtered := make([]*gtsmodel.Status, 0, len(statuses))
+	for _, s := range statuses {
+		visible, err := p.filter.StatusVisible(ctx, s, requestingAccount)
+		if err == nil && visible {
+			filtered = append(filtered, s)
+		}
+	}
+
+	count := len(filtered)
+
+	if count == 0 {
+		return util.EmptyPageableResponse(), nil
+	}
+
+	items := []interface{}{}
+	nextMaxIDValue := ""
+	prevMinIDValue := ""
+	for i, s := range filtered {
+		item, err := p.tc.StatusToAPIStatus(ctx, s, requestingAccount)
+		if err != nil {
+			return nil, gtserror.NewErrorInternalError(fmt.Errorf("error converting status to api: %s", err))
+		}
+
+		if i == count-1 {
+			nextMaxIDValue = item.GetID()
+		}
+
+		if i == 0 {
+			prevMinIDValue = item.GetID()
+		}
+
+		items = append(items, item)
+	}
+
+	return util.PackagePageableResponse(util.PageableResponseParams{
+		Items:            items,
+		Path:             "/api/v1/bookmarks",
+		NextMaxIDValue:   nextMaxIDValue,

issue.title: Redirect in imported pages throws an error
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.13

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

Node

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

When adding `Astro.redirect('/')` to a (imported) hidden page the application throws an error.
You can see the example in StackBlitz when navigating to `/en/search`

```
Returning a Response is only supported inside of page components. Consider refactoring this logic into something like a function that can be used in the page.
 error   {"size":0}
  File:
    /home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/file:/file:/home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/core/errors/utils.js:68:73
  Stacktrace:
Error: {"size":0}
    at Module.createSafeError (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/core/errors/utils.js:68:73)
    at onError (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/vite-plugin-astro-server/request.js:75:41)
    at Module.runWithErrorHandling (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/vite-plugin-astro-server/controller.js:86:19)
    at async Module.handleRequest (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/vite-plugin-astro-server/request.js:56:3)
```

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-kmhexi

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: You can only redirect from the top-level page. So in your case that would be in `src/pages/en/search.astro` or `src/pages/nl/zoeken.astro`. It's not a matter of where the component is located, if it's not used as a top-level page then it can't redirect (or return a response).

pull_request.title: Documented how to access the base config in the app
pull_request.body:
## Changes

While the `site` property in the Astro config can be accessed in the app via `Astro.site`, the `base` property is only accessible via `import.meta.env.BASE_URL`. It wasn't documented, so this PRs fixes this.

## Testing

No tests since it's just a docs change.

## Docs

This updates the types that are used to generate the reference pages (https://docs.astro.build/en/reference/).

issue.title: Add Astro.joinBase

labels.name: core
labels.description: PRs that modify the core `astro` package.

issue.body: Note that this PR is **just an experiment**. If it is successful then this might become an RFC. ## Motivation This PR is intended to aid when using `base` configuration in Astro. A common issue is that because Astro does not mutate your templates when you set things like `Contacts page ``` When using the base of `/docs/` that will produce `/docs/contacts`. ### join-base: directive However, since this is so commonly needed inside of the template this change also includes a directive `join-base:` which is used within your template to get the same effect, but without needing to create an expression and call the function. Here's the same example but used with the directive: ```astro Contacts page ``` ## Changes - Adds `Astro.joinBase` which can be used to join a URL to your configured `base`. `Astro.joinBase('/images/penguin.png')` becomes `/blog/images/penguin.png`. - Also updates the compiler which includes a `join-base:` directive to make it easier to use this feature within your template. ``` ``` ## Testing - None yet. Compiler has a test ## Docs - Docs added in Astro types - More needed, tbd

pull_request.title: [ci] release
pull_request.body:
This PR was opened by the [Changesets release](https://github.com/changesets/action) GitHub action. When you're ready to do a release, you can merge this and the packages will be published to npm automatically. If you're not ready to do a release yet, that's fine, whenever you add more changesets to main, this PR will be updated.


# Releases
## @astrojs/rss@1.1.0

### Minor Changes

-   [#5366](https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5366) [`081e0a9d2`](https://github.com/withastro/astro/commit/081e0a9d2070b23d596b687ad52ed3a68bc3ac24) Thanks [@smithbm2316](https://github.com/smithbm2316)! - Added the ability for users to include the full content of their posts/items in each RSS feed entry
    via the new `content` key on the `RSSFeedItem` model.

### Patch Changes

-   [#5550](https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5550) [`fe0da0185`](https://github.com/withastro/astro/commit/fe0da0185a85762ac5ac5bf66ea91947af1c329d) Thanks [@andersk](https://github.com/andersk)! - Generate RSS feed with proper XML escaping

## astro@1.6.14

### Patch Changes

-   [#5545](https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5545) [`9082a850e`](https://github.com/withastro/astro/commit/9082a850eef4ab0187fc3bfdd5a377f0c7040070) Thanks [@bluwy](https://github.com/bluwy)! - Exclude astro from Vite optimization

-   [#5446](https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5446) [`4f7f20616`](https://github.com/withastro/astro/commit/4f7f20616ed2b63f94ebf43bc5fdc1be55062a94) Thanks [@jyasskin](https://github.com/jyasskin)! - Fix redirect() typing to allow all redirection status codes.

-   [#5511](https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5511) [`05915fec0`](https://github.com/withastro/astro/commit/05915fec01a51f27ab5051644f01e6112ecf06bc) Thanks [@matthewp](https://github.com/matthewp)! - Low-level head propagation

    This adds low-level head propagation ability within the Astro runtime. This is not really useable within an Astro app at the moment, but provides the APIs necessary for `renderEntry` to do head propagation.

-   [#5553](https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5553) [`1aeabe417`](https://github.com/withastro/astro/commit/1aeabe417077505bc0cdb8d2e47366ddbc616072) Thanks [@matthewp](https://github.com/matthewp)! - Fix Astro.params not having values when using base in SSR

-   [#5539](https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5539) [`2c836b9d1`](https://github.com/withastro/astro/commit/2c836b9d1283a0707128d172e92ee2bba767486c) Thanks [@wulinsheng123](https://github.com/wulinsheng123)! - Error reporting fails on undefined error index

-   [#5548](https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5548) [`8f3f67c96`](https://github.com/withastro/astro/commit/8f3f67c96aee63be64de77f374293761ff73f6ce) Thanks [@ido-pluto](https://github.com/ido-pluto)! - Removed premature optimization

issue.title: Magic-string version causes errors with Threlte (svelte lib)
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

^1.6.13

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

no

### What package manager are you using?

npm, pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

Windows, Linux

### Describe the Bug

I was trying to implement a Threlte component. It's a Svelte library for Three.js and it uses it's own pre-processor. (https://threlte.xyz/getting-started#installation)

I am getting this error:
``` error   Error while preprocessing C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/src/components/App.svelte - markup.update is not a function
  File:
    C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/src/components/App.svelte
  Stacktrace:
TypeError: Error while preprocessing C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/src/components/App.svelte - markup.update is not a function
    at Object.enter (file:///C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/node_modules/@threlte/preprocess/dist/index.js:121:32)
```

This is a repo to reproduce the error. Stackblitz example doesn't build either but I don't see full error message (could be just me not knowing where it outputs :P )
[https://github.com/jerzakm/astro-threlte-issue](https://github.com/jerzakm/astro-threlte-issue)

**Why it's broken**
It is happening because `magicstring.update` was released in 26.6 and astro uses `"magic-string": "^0.25.9"`
https://github.com/Rich-Harris/magic-string/commit/7b45b9bbb9890e78bb683edccc9a667ef159ddc0

**Quick fix**
Simply installing magic-string inside the project as dev dependency fixes the issue
`npm i -D magic-string`

**Permanent fix proposal**
Update astro's `magic-string`. I am not familiar with astro internals so I'm not sure if this would cause any major problems. I'm willing to make a PR with it.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-wmsgt4?file=src/pages/index.astro

### Participation

- [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: @jerzakm a PR would be very welcome here!

issue.title: Body tags are missing when conditionally rendering Astro components in HTML head
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.13

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

When conditionally rendering an Astro slot or component in the HTML `head`, the opening and closing `body` tags provided by the template are completely stripped from the document.

I'm using said condition to differentiate between a production or development build, and it appears to not make a difference whether the condition evaluates to true or false. Only commenting out the code does lead to the body tags being correctly rendered.

There is no difference in behaviour between a production build or running the development server.

It is hardly noticeable when using an empty body tag, because browsers seem to be fault-tolerant and implicitly insert one (as one can see in the dev console), but I am putting CSS class names on the body element which I need for styling. In this example I used an inline style so it's visible more easily.

Both slot content and Astro component, as well as the rest of the document seem to be rendered correctly.

I can kind of work around the issue by wrapping everything inside body in an extra div and apply my classes there, but this might not apply to everyone, so this is totally unexpected to me.

```astro
---
const isProd = process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production'
---
<html lang="en">
	<head>
		<meta charset="utf-8" />
		<title>Astro</title>
		{isProd && <slot name="test" />}
	</head>
	<body style="background-color: red;">
		<slot />
	</body>
</html>
```

A minimal reproducible example that is also rendering an Astro component is provided below.


### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-uwb7te?file=src/pages/index.astro

astro-rss: Generate feed with proper XML escaping (#5550)

* test(astro-rss): Compare XML using chai-xml

Signed-off-by: Anders Kaseorg <andersk@mit.edu>

pull_request.title: astro-rss: Generate feed with proper XML escaping
pull_request.body:
## Changes

Generating XML using string concatenation is dangerous and can lead to underescaping.

Just to preemptively dismiss some excuses for this unsafety 😛:

- _“But most of the content was surrounded with with `<![CDATA[…]]>`, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. The content might contain `]]>` itself and break out of the `<![CDATA[` early.
- _“But URLs don’t need to be escaped, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. `&` commonly appears in URLs and needs to be escaped for XML or HTML serialization.
- _“But we were validating the output XML, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. A bug that’s caught at generation time is still a bug; also, some cases of underescaping could lead to incorrect output that isn’t invalid.
- _“But there’s no user-generated content for an attacker to control, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. Underescaping is still a bug even when it’s not a security vulnerability.

So let’s take the `fast-xml-parser` library that we were using to validate our hand-rolled XML, and use it to properly generate XML instead.

## Testing

I updated the existing tests to compare the XML using `chai-xml`, so that the snapshotted XML strings didn’t need to change. This verifies that the new output is semantically equivalent.

## Docs

This doesn’t need any documentation changes. I even preserve support for the existing `customData` option by parsing and re-serializing the XML string.

pull_request.title: Fix Astro.params not having values when using base in SSR
pull_request.body:
## Changes

- Internal rendering expects `pathname` to be trimmed of the base because routing is not aware of base.
- Fix is to provide the pathname without base to rendering.
- `url.pathname` is still the real pathname. The other `pathname` is just used for internal route/param matching and not provided to the user.
- Fixes https://github.com/withastro/astro/issues/5537

## Testing

- New test case added

## Docs

N/A, bug fix

issue.title: [feature] support access token passed as header

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem ?

In Mastodon the access token can be passed in through the header `Sec-WebSocket-Protocol` since https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/10818. GTS should support this too, as some clients are now using this.

### Describe the solution you'd like.

Check the query param first and fallback to the header if the query param is empty.

### Describe alternatives you've considered.

None

### Additional context.

I can submit a PR for this if accepted.

issue.title: an odd and unclear behaviour when using jsx-like syntax
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using? 1.6.12 ### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one? @astrojs/node@3.1.0 | Node.js version is 18.12.1 ### What package manager are you using? npm@9.1.3 ### What operating system are you using? Mac ### Describe the Bug When using the JSX-like syntax, the behaviour is a bit odd. Given this example, ```jsx --- const props = { class: "red" } ---

Should I be blue or red?

I'm neither blue or red.

I'm red.

``` The HTML output is, ```html

Should I be blue or red?

I'm neither blue or red.

I'm red.

``` The first `h1` is blue, so `props.class` is ignored. - This could benefit from a mention in docs, if it's intended The second `h1` is black, even though it receives the `red` class. - This seems like a bug The third `h1` is red. - This behaves as expected ### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-qkr4u8?file=src/pages/index.astro ### Participation - [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: I'm surprised that (2) does not receive the hash class name but (3) does. I would almost expect (3) not too, but then again I'm not super familiar with the hash assignment code. Maybe @natemoo-re has insight here.

+

+		return util.EmptyPageableResponse(), nil
+	}
+
+	items := []interface{}{}
+	nextMaxIDValue := ""
+	prevMinIDValue := ""
+	for i, s := range filtered {
+		item, err := p.tc.StatusToAPIStatus(ctx, s, requestingAccount)
+		if err != nil {
+			return nil, gtserror.NewErrorInternalError(fmt.Errorf("error converting status to api: %s", err))
+		}
+
+		if i == count-1 {
+			nextMaxIDValue = item.GetID()
+		}
+
+		if i == 0 {
+			prevMinIDValue = item.GetID()
+		}
+
+		items = append(items, item)
+	}
+
+	return util.PackagePageableResponse(util.PageableResponseParams{
+		Items:            items,
+		Path:             "/api/v1/bookmarks",
+		NextMaxIDValue:   nextMaxIDValue,

issue.title: Redirect in imported pages throws an error
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.13

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

Node

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

When adding `Astro.redirect('/')` to a (imported) hidden page the application throws an error.
You can see the example in StackBlitz when navigating to `/en/search`

```
Returning a Response is only supported inside of page components. Consider refactoring this logic into something like a function that can be used in the page.
 error   {"size":0}
  File:
    /home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/file:/file:/home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/core/errors/utils.js:68:73
  Stacktrace:
Error: {"size":0}
    at Module.createSafeError (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/core/errors/utils.js:68:73)
    at onError (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/vite-plugin-astro-server/request.js:75:41)
    at Module.runWithErrorHandling (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/vite-plugin-astro-server/controller.js:86:19)
    at async Module.handleRequest (file://file:///home/projects/qgniooaqx.github/node_modules/astro/dist/vite-plugin-astro-server/request.js:56:3)
```

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-kmhexi

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: You can only redirect from the top-level page. So in your case that would be in `src/pages/en/search.astro` or `src/pages/nl/zoeken.astro`. It's not a matter of where the component is located, if it's not used as a top-level page then it can't redirect (or return a response).

pull_request.body:
## Changes

While the `site` property in the Astro config can be accessed in the app via `Astro.site`, the `base` property is only accessible via `import.meta.env.BASE_URL`. It wasn't documented, so this PRs fixes this.

## Testing

No tests since it's just a docs change.

## Docs

This updates the types that are used to generate the reference pages (https://docs.astro.build/en/reference/).

issue.title: Add Astro.joinBase

labels.name: core
labels.description: PRs that modify the core `astro` package.

issue.body: Note that this PR is **just an experiment**. If it is successful then this might become an RFC. ## Motivation This PR is intended to aid when using `base` configuration in Astro. A common issue is that because Astro does not mutate your templates when you set things like `Contacts page ``` When using the base of `/docs/` that will produce `/docs/contacts`. ### join-base: directive However, since this is so commonly needed inside of the template this change also includes a directive `join-base:` which is used within your template to get the same effect, but without needing to create an expression and call the function. Here's the same example but used with the directive: ```astro Contacts page ``` ## Changes - Adds `Astro.joinBase` which can be used to join a URL to your configured `base`. `Astro.joinBase('/images/penguin.png')` becomes `/blog/images/penguin.png`. - Also updates the compiler which includes a `join-base:` directive to make it easier to use this feature within your template. ``` ``` ## Testing - None yet. Compiler has a test ## Docs - Docs added in Astro types - More needed, tbd

This PR was opened by the [Changesets release](https://github.com/changesets/action) GitHub action. When you're ready to do a release, you can merge this and the packages will be published to npm automatically. If you're not ready to do a release yet, that's fine, whenever you add more changesets to main, this PR will be updated.


# Releases
## @astrojs/rss@1.1.0

### Minor Changes

-   [#5366](https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5366) [`081e0a9d2`](https://github.com/withastro/astro/commit/081e0a9d2070b23d596b687ad52ed3a68bc3ac24) Thanks [@smithbm2316](https://github.com/smithbm2316)! - Added the ability for users to include the full content of their posts/items in each RSS feed entry
    via the new `content` key on the `RSSFeedItem` model.

### Patch Changes

issue.title: Magic-string version causes errors with Threlte (svelte lib)
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

^1.6.13

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

no

### What package manager are you using?

npm, pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

Windows, Linux

### Describe the Bug

I was trying to implement a Threlte component. It's a Svelte library for Three.js and it uses it's own pre-processor. (https://threlte.xyz/getting-started#installation)

I am getting this error:
``` error   Error while preprocessing C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/src/components/App.svelte - markup.update is not a function
  File:
    C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/src/components/App.svelte
  Stacktrace:
TypeError: Error while preprocessing C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/src/components/App.svelte - markup.update is not a function
    at Object.enter (file:///C:/Users/Firma/Documents/Github/astro-threlte-issue/node_modules/@threlte/preprocess/dist/index.js:121:32)
```

This is a repo to reproduce the error. Stackblitz example doesn't build either but I don't see full error message (could be just me not knowing where it outputs :P )
[https://github.com/jerzakm/astro-threlte-issue](https://github.com/jerzakm/astro-threlte-issue)

**Why it's broken**
It is happening because `magicstring.update` was released in 26.6 and astro uses `"magic-string": "^0.25.9"`
https://github.com/Rich-Harris/magic-string/commit/7b45b9bbb9890e78bb683edccc9a667ef159ddc0

**Quick fix**
Simply installing magic-string inside the project as dev dependency fixes the issue
`npm i -D magic-string`

**Permanent fix proposal**
Update astro's `magic-string`. I am not familiar with astro internals so I'm not sure if this would cause any major problems. I'm willing to make a PR with it.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-wmsgt4?file=src/pages/index.astro

### Participation

- [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: @jerzakm a PR would be very welcome here!

issue.title: Body tags are missing when conditionally rendering Astro components in HTML head
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.13

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

When conditionally rendering an Astro slot or component in the HTML `head`, the opening and closing `body` tags provided by the template are completely stripped from the document.

I'm using said condition to differentiate between a production or development build, and it appears to not make a difference whether the condition evaluates to true or false. Only commenting out the code does lead to the body tags being correctly rendered.

There is no difference in behaviour between a production build or running the development server.

It is hardly noticeable when using an empty body tag, because browsers seem to be fault-tolerant and implicitly insert one (as one can see in the dev console), but I am putting CSS class names on the body element which I need for styling. In this example I used an inline style so it's visible more easily.

Both slot content and Astro component, as well as the rest of the document seem to be rendered correctly.

I can kind of work around the issue by wrapping everything inside body in an extra div and apply my classes there, but this might not apply to everyone, so this is totally unexpected to me.

```astro
---
const isProd = process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production'
---
<html lang="en">
	<head>
		<meta charset="utf-8" />
		<title>Astro</title>
		{isProd && <slot name="test" />}
	</head>
	<body style="background-color: red;">
		<slot />
	</body>
</html>
```

A minimal reproducible example that is also rendering an Astro component is provided below.


### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-uwb7te?file=src/pages/index.astro

astro-rss: Generate feed with proper XML escaping (#5550)

* test(astro-rss): Compare XML using chai-xml

Signed-off-by: Anders Kaseorg <andersk@mit.edu>

pull_request.title: astro-rss: Generate feed with proper XML escaping
pull_request.body:
## Changes

Generating XML using string concatenation is dangerous and can lead to underescaping.

Just to preemptively dismiss some excuses for this unsafety 😛:

- _“But most of the content was surrounded with with `<![CDATA[…]]>`, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. The content might contain `]]>` itself and break out of the `<![CDATA[` early.
- _“But URLs don’t need to be escaped, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. `&` commonly appears in URLs and needs to be escaped for XML or HTML serialization.
- _“But we were validating the output XML, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. A bug that’s caught at generation time is still a bug; also, some cases of underescaping could lead to incorrect output that isn’t invalid.
- _“But there’s no user-generated content for an attacker to control, so it was fine!”_ Wrong. Underescaping is still a bug even when it’s not a security vulnerability.

So let’s take the `fast-xml-parser` library that we were using to validate our hand-rolled XML, and use it to properly generate XML instead.

## Testing

I updated the existing tests to compare the XML using `chai-xml`, so that the snapshotted XML strings didn’t need to change. This verifies that the new output is semantically equivalent.

## Docs

This doesn’t need any documentation changes. I even preserve support for the existing `customData` option by parsing and re-serializing the XML string.

pull_request.title: Fix Astro.params not having values when using base in SSR
pull_request.body:
## Changes

- Internal rendering expects `pathname` to be trimmed of the base because routing is not aware of base.
- Fix is to provide the pathname without base to rendering.
- `url.pathname` is still the real pathname. The other `pathname` is just used for internal route/param matching and not provided to the user.
- Fixes https://github.com/withastro/astro/issues/5537

## Testing

- New test case added

## Docs

N/A, bug fix
